description: From Middle English beggere, beggare, beggar (“beggar”), from Middle English beggen (“to beg”), equivalent to beg +‎ -ar.

Alternative etymology derives Middle English beggere, beggare, beggar from Old French begart, originally a member of the Beghards, a lay brotherhood of mendicants in the Low Countries, from Middle Dutch beggaert (“mendicant”), with pejorative suffix (see -ard); the order is said to be named after the priest Lambert le Bègue of Liège (French for “Lambert the Stammerer”).

examples: Odysseus has returned to his home disguised as a beggar.

entries.meaning: A person suffering from extreme poverty.
(colloquial, sometimes endearing) A mean or wretched person; a scoundrel.
examples: What does that silly beggar think he's doing?

verbs.description: beggar (third-person singular simple present beggars, present participle beggaring, simple past and past participle beggared)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a beggar of someone; impoverish.
(transitive, figurative) To exhaust the resources of; to outdo.
